meanings.definition: To press out or squeeze out.
meanings.sent1: She tried to outpress the juice from the orange by squeezing it hard.
meanings.sent2: The athlete had to outpress all his strength to lift the heavy weights.
meanings.sent3: The toothpaste tube seemed to outpress every last bit of paste, refusing to give up.
meanings.sent4: Her determination to succeed was so strong, it felt like she could outpress any obstacle in her way.
meanings.sent5: The old machine groaned as it struggled to outpress the oil from the olives.

meanings.definition: To surpass in pressing or squeezing.
meanings.sent1: In the arm-wrestling competition, he managed to outpress his opponent and win the match.
meanings.sent2: The hydraulic press was able to outpress any manual effort in flattening the metal sheets.
meanings.sent3: The competition was fierce as each participant tried to outpress the others in the grape stomping contest.
meanings.sent4: Her love for baking was so strong that she could outpress any doubts about her skills.
meanings.sent5: The giant python could easily outpress its prey, suffocating them with its powerful coils.

meanings.definition: To publish or produce more copies of a book than a rival publisher.
meanings.sent1: The author decided to outpress the competition by releasing a special edition of the book.
meanings.sent2: The small publishing house managed to outpress the big companies by focusing on niche markets.
meanings.sent3: The bookstore owner joked that he would outpress his rival by selling books in his sleep.
meanings.sent4: Her enthusiasm for the project was so contagious that it seemed she could outpress any doubts about its success.
meanings.sent5: The printing press worked tirelessly to outpress the demand for the latest bestseller.
